awd_titl_txt: Evaluating Mantle and Crustal Processes in Off-axis Volcanism on Iceland
awd_abstract_narration:
Most volcanoes in Iceland are concentrated in a NE-SW rift that traverses the center of the island. This rift marks where two tectonic plates are drifting apart, which causes the underlying mantle rocks to rise and melt, forming magma that creates volcanic eruptions at the surface. However, the reasons are less clear why some volcanoes are found in the Snaefellsnes Peninsula in the western part of Iceland (including Snaefellsjökull - made famous in Jules Verne's novel as the place where travellers could 'Journey to the Center of the Earth'). This project aims to understand why and how the mantle melts in this region by analysing the chemical composition of the lavas. From the size distribution and chemical composition of crystals of specific minerals in lavas, it is possible to determine how and where the crystals were formed, thereby revealing details of what was happening at depth beneath each volcano prior to lavas eruption. College-level teaching resources will be developed based on these samples that integrate chemical data sets with field photographs and a web-based digital virtual microscope, and made available to other educators. Public outreach activities will be coordinated through the University of Iowa Museum of Natural History, with the creation of a "Discovery Trunk" on Volcanoes for local schools to use, and participation in the Museum's public lecture series.


More attention has been given to melt generation and storage in the Iceland rift zones because of their dominance on melt production, but the reasons for melt generation at large (~100km+) distances from the rifts, like at Snaefellsnes, remain uncertain. This project will be the first in-depth study of primitive lavas in this off-axis zone that focuses on how melts are generated and transported to the surface, to investigate the underlying cause of melting and how details of melt aggregation and transport through thick lithosphere contrasts with the extensional setting and thinner lithosphere of the rift zones. Crystallization depths will be estimated from glass analyses (using ol-cpx-plag saturation) and clinopyroxene thermobarometry, and melt diversity will be characterized with olivine-hosted melt inclusions and clinopyroxene compositions. Radiogenic isotopes and U-series disequilibria will be used to provide insights into the compositional heterogeneity and melting behavior of mantle sources and the process of melt extraction, and additional constraints on the details of melting will come from REE inversion models. The potential of high-precision minor element analyses of olivines to show involvement of non-peridotite sources for off-axis magmas will also be evaluated. The project will provide training in research methods and data acquisition/interpretation for a Ph.D. student, and research experiences for undergraduates. Results will be disseminated through journal articles and conference presentations.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Most Iceland volcanoes are found in a NE-SW rift that marks where two tectonic plates are drifting apart. This causes the underlying mantle to rise and melt, forming magma that creates volcanism at the surface. Why some volcanoes (including Snaefellsjökull - made famous by Jules Verne as the place to 'Journey to the Center of the Earth') are found along the Snaefellsnes peninsula (W Iceland) was not understood. This project aimed to understand details of magma formation in Snaefellsnes by chemically analysing lavas and minerals.

Intellectual Merit: The main research goals of the project were successfully accomplished.
1. Detailed study of the composition of olivine and spinel crystals showed that the mantle lithology was peridotite not pyroxenite and that the mantle temperature decreased from east to west.
2. Chemical compositions of volcanic glass and clinopyroxene crystals showed that rising melts initially pond at the crust-mantle boundary (~25 km depth) before storage in magma chambers in the mid-crust.
3. Differences in lava compositions, erupted lava volumes, and maximum crystallization temperatures indicate a major boundary at about 22.3 deg W that separates two fundamentally different melt generation regimes: A. small magma volumes produced from the deep periphery of the Western Volcanic Zone rift in the east, and B. large magma volumes related to decompression melting of outflow mantle beneath the thinner lithosphere of the trace of the abandoned Hunafloi-Snaefellsnes rift zone in the west.

Broader Impacts: Over the course of the project, three undergraduate and four graduate students were trained in research methods and in acquisition and interpretation of chemical data, and they presented their results at several national and international conferences. We also collaborated with scientists at the University of Iceland, which was valuable in fostering international relations. College-level teaching resources have been developed that integrate chemical data sets with field photographs and microscope images.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2021
Modified by: David W Peate
